subjectDescription: Discover a full suite of online business courses that will allow you to make better business decisions and succeed in today's competitive business world. Our courses provide a rich learning experience that will allow you to develop critical business skills in areas such as business... Read more...
title: Cash Flow Management Basics
headline: Learn about Cash Management, Profitability, and Financial Ratios, with this free online cash flow management course.
description: This free online accounting course teaches you all of the skills that you need to conduct liquidity and profitability ratio analysis, and assess the impact that changes-in-costs have on financial statements. In this course you will also learn about how these relate to a company's financial targets, and gain a strong theoretical and practical understanding of liquidity, efficiency, profitability, leverage ratios, and more.

Make the calculation of LIQUIDITY Ra...
Discuss the information contained in the Income Statement and Balance Sheet essential to obtain financial ratios.
Explain ratios based on the Balance Sheet and the Income Statement.
Make the calculation of LIQUIDITY Ratios, EFFICIENCY Ratios, PROFITABILITY Ratios and LEVERAGE Ratios.
Interpret financial ratios of simulated ‘real’ companies.
Compare financial ratios of simulated ‘real’ companies. Use of ratio analysis from the point of view of lenders and investors.
Explain ratios based on the Balance ...
Make the calculation of LIQUIDITY Ra...
Discuss the information contained in the Income Statement and Balance Sheet essential to obtain financial ratios.
Explain ratios based on the Balance Sheet and the Income Statement.
Make the calculation of LIQUIDITY Ratios, EFFICIENCY Ratios, PROFITABILITY Ratios and LEVERAGE Ratios.
Interpret financial ratios of simulated ‘real’ companies.
Compare financial ratios of simulated ‘real’ companies. Use of ratio analysis from the point of view of lenders and investors.
courseDescription:
This course will first introduce you to cash flow management and give you a strong understanding of liquidity, efficiency, profitability, and leverage ratios. You will also look into the most important types of financial ratios, and be shown how to apply them in practical situations that commonly arise in a fiscal year. You will then be guided through the process of assessing impacts that changes in revenue and costs can have on financial statements.

Next, you will study how Ratio Analysis is used by prospective lenders and investors. Here, you will learn how to use the information contained in the Income Statement and Balance Sheet to obtain financial ratios. The course then explains, with examples, the relationship between the absolute values of sales, costs, expenses, assets, liabilities, and equity. This can be used as a base for understanding the financial position of a company and its likely performance in the future.

Managing cash flow efficiently is essential in any business. This course will teach you the skills you need to analyse Balance Sheets and Income Statements, calculate and interpret financial ratios, and implement actions to reach key financial targets of liquidity. Every accounting professional and business owner needs to learn these skills. So, check out the course today, improve your understanding of these key accounting principles, and keep your company's finances running smoothly.

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this certificate course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this certificate course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison certificate is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital certificate: a downloadable certificate in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked certificate, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed certificate: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked certificate in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All certificate are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison certificate, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison certificate, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our certificate pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: This module focuses on the information contained in the Income Statement and Balance Sheet essential to obtain financial ratios. It gives practical examples on the relation between the absolute values of sales, costs, expenses, assets, liabilities and equity as a base to understand the financial position of a company and its likely performance in the future. It explains the use of financial ratios in management decisions targeted at improved business performance and sustainable growth.
topics: Financial Ratios Based on the Balance Sheet
Financial Ratios Based on the Income Statement
Examples on Calculation and Interpretation of Financial Ratios
Case Study - Conclusion on Financial Evaluation
Use of Ratio Analysis by Prospective Lenders and Investors

modules.name: Module
topics: Module 2: Cash Flow Management Basics Assessment

slides:
• Upon completion of this module you will be able to:
    • Discuss the information contained in the Income Statement and Balance Sheet essential to obtain financial ratios.
    • Explain ratios based on the Balance Sheet.
    • Explain ratios based on the Income Statement.
    • Make the calculation of LIQUIDITY Ratios (current ratio, quick ratio, working capital).
    • Make the calculation of EFFICIENCY Ratios (asset turnover, inventory turn, debtors days).
    • Make the calculation of PROFITABILITY Ratios (gross profit, net profit margin, return on assets, return on equity, return on initial capital).
    • Make the calculation of LEVERAGE Ratios (debt-to-asset, debt-to-equity).
    • Interpret financial ratios of simulated ‘real’ companies.
    • Compare of financial ratios of simulated ‘real’ companies.
    • Use ratio analysis from the point of view of lenders and investors.
  • By learning how to calculate, interpret and use financial ratios you will understand how to assess the financial strength of a firm, to analyse management effectiveness in employing capital, and how solvent and profitable is the company.

    The information contained in the Income Statement and Balance Sheet is essential to obtain financial ratios:

    (a) liquidity ratios; 
    (b) effectiveness ratios; 
    (c) profitability ratios
    (d) leverage ratios.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

    • Gross Margin Ratio 
      Gross Margin Ratio indicates the percentage of sales available for expenses and profit after the cost of sales is deducted from revenue. The gross margin varies between industries and often varies between companies within the same industry. A Gross Margin ratio of 0.48 or 48% indicates that 52% on the value of revenue is available to cover running expenses, financial costs, tax and profit. It is a good level of gross margin.
      Gross Margin Ratio indicates the percentage of sales available for expenses and profit after the cost of sales is deducted from revenue. The gross margin varies between industries and often varies between companies within the same industry. A Gross Margin ratio of 0.48 or 48% indicates that 52% on the value of revenue is available to cover running expenses, financial costs, tax and profit. It is a good level of gross margin.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Net Profit Margin
      Net Profit Margin indicates the profit relative to sales after all expenses are deducted from gross margin. This margin will vary between industries as well as between companies in the same industry. A profit margin of 10% over sales is considered satisfactory and means that for every pound of sales the company makes 10% profit.
      Net Profit Margin indicates the profit relative to sales after all expenses are deducted from gross margin. This margin will vary between industries as well as between companies in the same industry. A profit margin of 10% over sales is considered satisfactory and means that for every pound of sales the company makes 10% profit.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • Return on Equity Ratio (ROE)
      Return on Equity Ratio (ROE) shows the percentage of net profit over equity after interest and income taxes. If a corporation has preferred shares, the preferred dividends must be deducted from the net income. A ROE of 0.32 or 32% is a very good return. When compared with the rate of interest on savings if investor's funds are kept, say, in a bank, a 32% ROE is well above the bank savings rate, which typically varies from 2 to 5% depending on which country and whether short or long term savings.

      The ROE also takes account of the risk facing investors when committing funds in the firm.

      Thus investing in the firm is considered a profitable investment for shareholders. The ROE above compares with the return from other investments available to shareholders, as is the case with shares in the stock exchange, government bonds, currency trading, real estate.

      Return on Equity Ratio (ROE) shows the percentage of net profit over equity after interest and income taxes. If a corporation has preferred shares, the preferred dividends must be deducted from the net income. A ROE of 0.32 or 32% is a very good return. When compared with the rate of interest on savings if investor's funds are kept, say, in a bank, a 32% ROE is well above the bank savings rate, which typically varies from 2 to 5% depending on which country and whether short or long term savings.

      The ROE also takes account of the risk facing investors when committing funds in the firm.

      Thus investing in the firm is considered a profitable investment for shareholders. The ROE above compares with the return from other investments available to shareholders, as is the case with shares in the stock exchange, government bonds, currency trading, real estate.

    • Description
      The two retail companies below have the following Income Statements and Balance Sheets at the end of their third year of operation. Net profit for both companies have remained equal to zero in the first two years of operation, thus equity has remained with the same value than at the start of operation after these two years. Net Profit in the third year is equal for both firms, 36,000.

      Opening equity is 125,000, for both companies. Drawings by shareholders were 16,000 in both companies.
      In order to boost sales Company A offers 60 days credit to their buyers.

    • Current Ratios Analysis
      Interest payable 18,000 for Company A and 9,000 for Company B. There are no long term debts in both cases, but short term credit is very expensive for Company A.Both current ratios are greater than 1.0, so they are both acceptable ratios.

      However, the acid test ratio shows that Company B has liquidity problems, its quick ratio is well below 1.0, it may be unable to pay its short term obligations, even face bankruptcy.

      Thus it can be seen that although the two firms have the same profits, 36,000, Company B is insolvent as judging by the acid test. Any potential investor or lender may consider Company B at risk of insolvency and will severely limit the ability of the company to raise finance.

      Interest payable 18,000 for Company A and 9,000 for Company B. There are no long term debts in both cases, but short term credit is very expensive for Company A.Both current ratios are greater than 1.0, so they are both acceptable ratios.

      Thus it can be seen that although the two firms have the same profits, 36,000, Company B is insolvent as judging by the acid test. Any potential investor or lender may consider Company B at risk of insolvency and will severely limit the ability of the company to raise finance.

    • Interest Coverage Ratios Analysis
      Company A has a low interest coverage ratio, 2.0, and it indicates a financial risk as if profit does not materialise as expected in the following year and it drops, to say half profit, the company will barely be able to pay financial charges.

      On the contrary Company B has a much higher ratio, 4.0, indicating a low risk of insolvency and a greater ability to pay for the external financing. Profits would have to fall substantially for the company to be unable interest charges. Company B has a higher chance than Company A to raise further finance. Both companies have the same level of debt, 50,000.

      The low interest coverage ratio reflects in the high cost of money for Company A, as creditors may be not very happy to provide credit to this company given the perceived inability of Company A to service the debt.

      Company A has a low interest coverage ratio, 2.0, and it indicates a financial risk as if profit does not materialise as expected in the following year and it drops, to say half profit, the company will barely be able to pay financial charges.

      The low interest coverage ratio reflects in the high cost of money for Company A, as creditors may be not very happy to provide credit to this company given the perceived inability of Company A to service the debt.

    • Working Capital Analysis
      It can be seen that despite that Company B has sold more than Company A as shown in the Income Statement above, the former has a lower working capital, 60,000, than the latter, 80,000, due to:
      • Company A total current assets, 130,000, are higher than total current assets of Company B, 110,000. Current liabilities are equal for both companies.
      • However, is not the total amount that matters but the composition of these assets in relation to cash or the quick convertibility to cash.
      • Thus Cash at Bank is higher for Company A, 30,000, versus 15,000 for Company B. Also Debtors is higher for Company A, 60,000, versus 20,000 for Company B. These two items mean quick access to cash. Very important!!
      • On the contrary Stock is higher for Company B, 75,000, versus 40,000 for Company A. It is always much more difficult to quickly convert stock into cash, if in need to do so.
      • Thus it can be said that the liquidity risk of Company A is much less that of Company B. It also true that Company A can raise financing more easily that Company B as lenders and creditors will view Company A as having a higher ability to pay interest of the credits and even the principal itself.

      Thus it can be seen that although the two firms have the same profits, 36,000, Company B is insolvent as judging by the acid test. Any potential investor or lender may consider Company B at risk of insolvency and will severely limit the ability of the company to raise finance.

      Customer Name

    • Interest Coverage Ratios Analysis
      Company A has a low interest coverage ratio, 2.0, and it indicates a financial risk as if profit does not materialise as expected in the following year and it drops, to say half profit, the company will barely be able to pay financial charges.

      On the contrary Company B has a much higher ratio, 4.0, indicating a low risk of insolvency and a greater ability to pay for the external financing. Profits would have to fall substantially for the company to be unable interest charges. Company B has a higher chance than Company A to raise further finance. Both companies have the same level of debt, 50,000.

      The low interest coverage ratio reflects in the high cost of money for Company A, as creditors may be not very happy to provide credit to this company given the perceived inability of Company A to service the debt.

    • Working Capital Analysis
      It can be seen that despite that Company B has sold more than Company A as shown in the Income Statement above, the former has a lower working capital, 60,000, than the latter, 80,000, due to:
      • Company A total current assets, 130,000, are higher than total current assets of Company B, 110,000. Current liabilities are equal for both companies.
      • However, is not the total amount that matters but the composition of these assets in relation to cash or the quick convertibility to cash.
      • Thus Cash at Bank is higher for Company A, 30,000, versus 15,000 for Company B. Also Debtors is higher for Company A, 60,000, versus 20,000 for Company B. These two items mean quick access to cash. Very important!!
      • On the contrary Stock is higher for Company B, 75,000, versus 40,000 for Company A. It is always much more difficult to quickly convert stock into cash, if in need to do so.
      • Thus it can be said that the liquidity risk of Company A is much less that of Company B. It also true that Company A can raise financing more easily that Company B as lenders and creditors will view Company A as having a higher ability to pay interest of the credits and even the principal itself.
